comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: I was not too far away from that spot today at 11 am on 11/11/11 and I prayed for all those who had died in that war.  It is interesting that so soon after independence so many people would turn out for a commemoration like that.  The rot of intolerance must have come later?  Look at the people on the roofs of Trinity - Health and Safety would have a hissy fit today!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] Checked the newspaper reports, and it was obvious that everyone was trying their best, but there were tensions! Look how controversial the whole topic of poppy-wearing is to this day, let alone so close after WWI, the Easter Rising, the War of Independence and the Civil War...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 50969511@N02
comment._content: We forget sometimes what Armistice day means

comment.author: 68985493@N06
comment._content: This is fascinating and deeply moving ... as a Canadian with Irish roots in my ancestry, I am eternally grateful and humbled by the selfless bravery exemplified here.
